Dina Merrill Finance Overview

Inheritance from Marjorie Merriweather Post

Dina Merrill’s financial foundation was significantly influenced by her inheritance from her mother, Marjorie Merriweather Post. Post was the heiress to the Post Cereals fortune, which she inherited in 1914.

Adjusted for inflation, this inheritance was equivalent to approximately $5 billion at the time of Dina Merrill’s death. This substantial wealth provided a solid financial base for Dina Merrill, ensuring her place among America’s wealthiest individuals.

Contributions from Edward Francis Hutton

In addition to her mother’s wealth, she benefited from her father, Edward Francis Hutton. Hutton was a prominent Wall Street stockbroker and founder of E. F. Hutton & Co., one of the most influential brokerage firms of its time.

The combination of inheritances from both parents played a crucial role in establishing Dina Merrill’s immense net worth.

Acting Career

She carved out a successful career in Hollywood, starring in numerous films and television series from the 1950s to the early 2000s.

Some of her notable works include Desk Set, Operation Petticoat, and Butterfield 8. Her earnings from acting, while significant, were overshadowed by her inheritance. Nonetheless, her career added to her financial stability and public profile.

Business Ventures and Investments

Beyond acting, she was also involved in several business ventures.

She co-founded Pavilion Communications and later merged it with RKO Pictures, creating a new company that managed the intellectual property of the RKO Radio Pictures movie studio. These business moves further solidified her financial standing and demonstrated her acumen in managing and growing her wealth.

Mar-a-Lago Resort and Other Properties

One of the notable properties associated with Dina Merrill is the Mar-a-Lago resort. Initially constructed by her mother, the resort was a significant asset.

Although the property was later sold, it showcased the family’s prominence and their involvement in high-value real estate. Merrill’s other real estate investments, including her estate in East Hampton, also contributed to her overall wealth.

Philanthropic Activities and Social Influence

She was not only wealthy but also a renowned philanthropist. She supported numerous charitable causes and served on the boards of several organizations, such as the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts and the Eugene O’Neill Theater Center.

Her social influence and philanthropic efforts added a layer of respect and admiration to her public persona.

Awards and Recognitions

Throughout her life, she received various awards and recognitions, including the Women’s International Center Living Legacy Award and a Lifetime Achievement Award from the American Academy of Dramatic Arts.

These accolades highlighted her contributions to the arts and her impact on society, further enhancing her legacy.

Marriages and Financial Partnerships

Dina Merrill’s marriages also played a role in her financial narrative. She was married to Stanley M. Rumbough Jr., Cliff Robertson, and Ted Hartley.

Each partnership brought its financial dynamics, with joint ventures and shared assets influencing her overall wealth. While her marriages contributed to her financial story, her primary wealth source remained her inheritance.

Legacy and Impact on Future Generations

She left a significant legacy for her children and future generations. Her financial planning ensured that her wealth would continue to benefit her family long after her passing.

Her influence extended beyond her lifetime, impacting both her descendants and the various philanthropic causes she supported.
